Award.AwardTitle: Gauge Theory, Floer Homology, and Invariants of Low-Dimensional Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award funds research to study three- and four-dimensional spaces with knotted curves and surfaces embedded within them. Such objects are of particular interest to scientists because of their connection to our physical world and the space-time continuum. These studies will deepen the understanding of our universe. Moreover, the theory of knotted curves has seen broad applications in other fields of science, for example, in investigations of the structure of DNA and that of protein molecules. In recent years, several new techniques have been introduced to study these low dimensional spaces. This project will be devoted to further developing the techniques, providing surprising insights and proving unexpected relationships between existing theories. In collaborative research, the PI will explore new invariants that would help us distinguish between different spaces.

This project is devoted to enhancing the power of gauge theory and Floer homology and applying these tools to the study of three- and four-dimensional manifolds. In the first part of this project, joint with Tirasan Khandhawit and Hirofumi Sasahira, the PI will further develop the theory of unfolded Seiberg-Witten Floer spectrum invariants for general three-manifolds and use it to draw new conclusions regarding four-manifolds. In the second part of this project, joint with Daniel Ruberman and Nikolai Saveliev, the PI will carry out research on invariants of four-manifolds with homology identical to the space obtained as a product of a circle with a three sphere, with surprising applications in the study of the three-dimensional homology cobordism group. In the third part of this project, the PI will seek for a sheaf theoretic description of invariants from gauge theory, with the goal to make these invariants more flexible and powerful.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project concerned 3 and 4 dimensional manifolds, which are generalizations of surfaces in higher dimensions. Studying the shape of manifolds has been a central topic in topology. An important direction has been defining new invariants of manifolds and studying their properties. In the project, we focused on the Seiberg-Witten theory, which studies manifolds by investigating the Seiberg-Witten equations (a set of partial differential equations introduced by Witten) over them. The classical Seiberg invariant is defined by counting solutions of the Seiberg-Witten equations. It has been a powerful tool in distinguishing smooth structures in dimension 4. The Seiberg-Witten invariant has a homotopy refinement called the Bauer-Furuta invariant, which contains even more information. In a joint work with Tirasan Khandhawit and Hirofumi Sasahir, the PI developed a gluing theory for the Bauer-Furuta invariant. The main result allows one to compute the Bauer-Furuta invariant by cutting a closed 4-manifold open along a general 3-manifold and computing the relative invariant. In a different direction, in a joint project with Daniel Ruberman and Nikolai Saveliev, the PI studied the Seiberg-Witten invariant for 4-manifolds which homologically resemble the product of a circle and a 3-sphere. The outcomes are a splitting formula, which expresses the invariant in terms of Floer theoretic data and a Lefschetz number formula, which related this invariant with another classical invariant called knot signature. We successfully discovered several applications of these formulas in knot theory, contact homology, gauge theory and 4-dimensional topology. Moreover, in a joint project with Mike Hopkins, XiaoLin Danny Shi and Zhouli Xu, the PI applied the powerful tool of equivariant homotopy theory to study the Bauer-Furuta invariant. We resolved a conjecture raised by Furuta and Jones concerning the existence of equivariant maps between certain spheres. Our solution of the conjecture leads to the strongest known result toward the famous 11/8-conjecture on homeomorphism classification of simply connected smooth 4-manifolds. Using a similar technique, the PI establishes the first exotic pair of diffeomorphisms on simply connected 4-manifolds that survive under a single stabilization.  The PI has disseminated this work through talks at 7 conferences, 20 specialized seminars, and 3 departmental colloquia. He also gave a lecture series aimed at graduate students and researchers in summer 2017.


Last Modified: 09/30/2020
Modified by: Jianfeng Lin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project concerned 3 and 4 dimensional manifolds, which are generalizations of surfaces in higher dimensions. Studying the shape of manifolds has been a central topic in topology. An important direction has been defining new invariants of manifolds and studying their properties. In the project, we focused on the Seiberg-Witten theory, which studies manifolds by investigating the Seiberg-Witten equations (a set of partial differential equations introduced by Witten) over them. The classical Seiberg invariant is defined by counting solutions of the Seiberg-Witten equations. It has been a powerful tool in distinguishing smooth structures in dimension 4. The Seiberg-Witten invariant has a homotopy refinement called the Bauer-Furuta invariant, which contains even more information. In a joint work with Tirasan Khandhawit and Hirofumi Sasahir, the PI developed a gluing theory for the Bauer-Furuta invariant. The main result allows one to compute the Bauer-Furuta invariant by cutting a closed 4-manifold open along a general 3-manifold and computing the relative invariant. In a different direction, in a joint project with Daniel Ruberman and Nikolai Saveliev, the PI studied the Seiberg-Witten invariant for 4-manifolds which homologically resemble the product of a circle and a 3-sphere. The outcomes are a splitting formula, which expresses the invariant in terms of Floer theoretic data and a Lefschetz number formula, which related this invariant with another classical invariant called knot signature. We successfully discovered several applications of these formulas in knot theory, contact homology, gauge theory and 4-dimensional topology. Moreover, in a joint project with Mike Hopkins, XiaoLin Danny Shi and Zhouli Xu, the PI applied the powerful tool of equivariant homotopy theory to study the Bauer-Furuta invariant. We resolved a conjecture raised by Furuta and Jones concerning the existence of equivariant maps between certain spheres. Our solution of the conjecture leads to the strongest known result toward the famous 11/8-conjecture on homeomorphism classification of simply connected smooth 4-manifolds. Using a similar technique, the PI establishes the first exotic pair of diffeomorphisms on simply connected 4-manifolds that survive under a single stabilization. The PI has disseminated this work through talks at 7 conferences, 20 specialized seminars, and 3 departmental colloquia. He also gave a lecture series aimed at graduate students and researchers in summer 2017. Last Modified: 09/30/2020 Submitted by: Jianfeng Lin
